body:
Yes I get annoyed by this sometimes too!

Do you fancy any of
- researching how to detect which region a bucket is in?
- how to find the correct endpoint?
- writing the code?

The SDK docs are here: https://godoc.org/github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go/service/s3

Ideally this would work for non AWS also.

Here is the API endpoint and the documentation:
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/RESTBucketGETlocation.html

I don't know what is the difference between "researching how to detect which region a bucket is in?" and "how to find the correct endpoint?". We can just run this query and get the correct parameter for `--s3-region`.
I've been having a go with this... It is harder than I first thought, so watch this space!

Here is a version of rclone which will auto detect regions.

If the region is incorrect on an operation, then rclone will query the region, remake the session with the new region and retry the operation.

Can you have a go?

https://beta.rclone.org/branch/v1.45-094-g2f82791b-fix-2915-s3-autoregion-beta/ (uploaded in 15-30 mins)
I've merged this to master now which means it will be in [the latest beta](https://beta.rclone.org) in 15-30 mins and released in v1.46

Hello,

Currently discovering rclone. 
I would like to use it to list the contents of some buckets. 

I dont understand why i am getting the error below while the fix for this issue is present :  

```
$ rclone -vv ls remote:mybucket
rclone -vv ls remote:mybucket
2019/11/12 13:23:58 DEBUG : rclone: Version "v1.50.1" starting with parameters ["rclone" "-vv" "ls" "remote:mubucket"]
2019/11/12 13:23:58 DEBUG : Using config file from "/home/user/.config/rclone/rclone.conf"
2019/11/12 13:23:59 ERROR : S3 bucket mybucket: Failed to update region for bucket: reading bucket location failed: AccessDenied: Access Denied
	status code: 403, request id: 1D2404EE0F711B4C, host id: RQCh4VTUxs7szZklnUPRHPV4cgMdC6vfxM70ipx4knglpsGSYhsnE7XxVOE9z0gB5UB08J/syRs=
2019/11/12 13:23:59 Failed to ls: BucketRegionError: incorrect region, the bucket is not in 'us-east-1' region at endpoint 'https://s3.amazonaws.com/'
	status code: 301, request id: , host id: 
```

thank you.

rclone calls [get bucket location](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/API/API_GetBucketLocation.html) to read the bucket location, however it doesn't have enough permissions for that hence the `AccessDenied` message and the return of the original message `BucketRegionError`

Thank you for your prompt answer.

One last question : is there any way i could get the same result as : 

```aws s3 ls --recursive --no-sign-request  s3://mybucket```   

( while  "mybucket" is publicly readable, no need to provide any region to get the output ) 

with rclone ?
 
I expect it to be : 

```rclone  --s3-provider=AWS  ls :s3:mybucket```

but still i need to work around the `BucketRegionError` problem

thank you.

> I expect it to be :
> 
> `rclone --s3-provider=AWS ls :s3:mybucket`
> 
> but still i need to work around the `BucketRegionError` problem

That should work, but if you are getting that error then maybe you need to add `--s3-region` too?

Sure, it does when i provide ```--s3-region```, but i would like  ```rclone ls``` to handle it as ```aws ls``` does ( that is the bucket content is retrieved without the need to provide the region )     :)
Can you figure out how `aws ls` does it?  That is which API methods it calls?

I am wondering if in your aws cli configure, the default region is set to the same one as s3. I have tried aws cli myself and if the region does not match it gives error. @VinceD2049 

You can check your default region by `cat ~/.aws/config`.

> I am wondering if in your aws cli configure, the default region is set to the same one as s3. I have tried aws cli myself and if the region does not match it gives error. @VinceD2049
> 
> You can check your default region by `cat ~/.aws/config`.

@Yexiaoxing @ncw, thank you again both of you for your inputs.

Here is the test i have been doing. I used the bucket "screenshotstest" which is publicly readable. 

1. I  rename my .aws directory then i am sure no aws conf file will be used : 

```
$ ls -ad ~/.aws*
/home/test/.aws.back
```

2. I run  both the cli **aws** and **rclone** with the correct parameters to get a listing of the bucket  "screenshotstest"

```
$ aws  --no-sign-request s3 ls --recursive  s3://screenshotstest
```

-> I get my listing

```
$ rclone  --s3-provider=AWS  ls :s3:screenshotstest
2019/11/13 10:22:59 NOTICE: Config file "/home/vdr/.config/rclone/rclone.conf" not found - using defaults
2019/11/13 10:23:00 ERROR : S3 bucket screenshotstest: Failed to update region for bucket: reading bucket location failed: AccessDenied: Access Denied
	status code: 403, request id: D5229B28EA90D49D, host id: ueHOl2AO7EcwNsaNOdBMAVelZeyntPPsZTKcyF+btjXPjw+Sfp2M1MCG+RmwEBULXx5iPDuAEw8=
2019/11/13 10:23:00 Failed to ls: BucketRegionError: incorrect region, the bucket is not in 'us-east-1' region at endpoint 'https://s3.amazonaws.com/'
	status code: 301, request id: , host id: 
```

-> i get the "Access Denied" error ( because i dont have permissions to the get the location for the bucket "screenshotstest" )
 
3. Luckily, i know which region the bucket has been created from :

```
$ rclone  --s3-provider=AWS  --s3-region us-east-2 ls :s3:screenshotstest
```

-> i get my listing

===

Hence i think the problem is that rclone will try a "GetBucketLocation"  and get a AccessDenied, even if in a case of a publicly readable bucket, the bucket content could be listen ( without the  need of getting the bucket location )

@ncw 

> Can you figure out how aws ls does it? That is which API methods it calls?

I cant tell you... i think it just relies on the DNS resolution of the bucket name without the need of calling the ```GetBucketLocation``` function

``` 2019-11-13 18:15:53,254 - MainThread - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - Starting new HTTPS connection (1): screenshotstest.s3.ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com:443 2019-11-13 18:15:53,616 - MainThread - urllib3.connectionpool - DEBUG - https://screenshotstest.s3.ap-northeast-1.amazonaws.com:443 "GET /?list-type=2&prefix=&encoding-type=url HTTP/1.1" 301 None 2019-11-13 18:15:53,617 - MainThread - botocore.parsers - DEBUG - Response headers: {'x-amz-bucket-region': 'us-east-2', 'x-amz-request-id': '10EC112584030C88', 'x-amz-id-2': 'MgzZaxS1XI5e3aJBBLNZM9HnMpXWzWVvyftyHnYN4lK5hl1Lo7OXZT6caDsl/+d3KhSsu6utcy0=', 'Content-Type': 'application/xml', 'Transfer-Encoding': 'chunked', 'Date': 'Wed, 13 Nov 2019 10:15:53 GMT', 'Server': 'AmazonS3'} 2019-11-13 18:15:53,617 - MainThread - botocore.parsers - DEBUG - Response body: b'\nPermanentRedirectThe bucket you are attempting to access must be addressed using the specified endpoint. Please send all future requests to this endpoint.screenshotstest.s3.us-east-2.amazonaws.comscreenshotstest10EC112584030C88MgzZaxS1XI5e3aJBBLNZM9HnMpXWzWVvyftyHnYN4lK5hl1Lo7OXZT6caDsl/+d3KhSsu6utcy0=' ``` The list object API is generating a 301 redirect, I think that's the reason why aws cli can discover the location. From aws sdk, actually it is catched and handled. We might make use of this logic. ```go if r.HTTPResponse.StatusCode == http.StatusMovedPermanently { msg := fmt.Sprintf( "incorrect region, the bucket is not in '%s' region at endpoint '%s'", aws.StringValue(r.Config.Region), aws.StringValue(r.Config.Endpoint), ) if v := r.HTTPResponse.Header.Get("x-amz-bucket-region"); len(v) != 0 { msg += fmt.Sprintf(", bucket is in '%s' region", v) } r.Error = awserr.NewRequestFailure( awserr.New("BucketRegionError", msg, nil), r.HTTPResponse.StatusCode, r.RequestID, ) return } ```
